externalDocs.description: See documentation for Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

info.description: Manage user logins and registrations by using OAuth and OpenID Connect.
info.title: Akamai: Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

get.description: Logs a user out from a Hosted Login session. This brings the session to a close without expiring or otherwise invalidating the user’s access and refresh tokens. You don't need authorization to call this endpoint.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

parameters.description: Unique identifier of the OpenID Connect login client making the authorization request. Use the [Get OpenID Connect clients](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-hosted-login/reference/get-oidc-clients) operation to return the IDs of your OpenID Connect clients.
parameters.name: clientId

parameters.description: URL that Hosted Login redirects a user to after that user logs out. You can redirect a user to any URL, including URLs that don't belong to your organization, as long as that URL is in the `redirectURIs` property of your OpenID Connect client.
parameters.name: redirect_uri

parameters.description: Random string value in a logout request. This helps protect against cross-site request forgeries (CSRF). After a user logs out, Hosted Login redirects the user to the URL in the `redirect_uri` parameter. At the same time, Hosted Login adds this value to the redirect URL. That value needs to match the value of the `state` parameter from the original logout request. If the values don't match that could indicate a cross-site request forgery attack.
parameters.name: state

200.description: User logout successful. Note that this operation doesn't return a response. Instead, it redirects the user to a new browser page.

get.description: Opens the **Manage Profile** screen for the user. Note that you don't need authentication to call this operation. Instead, the operation relies on a cookie that points to an active Hosted Login session. If this cookie doesn’t exist the operation fails with a `No authenticated session found` error. To access their user profile the user needs to log in. You don't need authorization to call this endpoint.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

parameters.description: Unique identifier of the OpenID Connect login client making the authorization request. Use the [Get OpenID Connect clients](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-hosted-login/reference/get-oidc-clients) operation to return the IDs of your OpenID Connect clients.
parameters.name: clientId

parameters.description: URL that Hosted Login redirects a user to after that user logs out. You can redirect a user to any URL, including URLs that don't belong to your organization, as long as that URL is in the `redirectURIs` property of your OpenID Connect client.
parameters.name: redirect_uri

parameters.description: Random string value in a logout request. This helps protect against cross-site request forgeries (CSRF). After a user logs out, Hosted Login redirects the user to the URL in the `redirect_uri` parameter. At the same time, Hosted Login adds this value to the redirect URL. That value needs to match the value of the `state` parameter from the original logout request. If the values don't match that could indicate a cross-site request forgery attack.
parameters.name: state

200.description: **Manage Profile** screen access successful. Note that this operation doesn't return a response. Instead, it redirects the user to a new browser page.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

schema.description: Creates an OpenID Connect (OIDC) client.

loginPolicy.description: Unique identifier of the OIDC client's login policy. OpenID Connect clients that handle user registrations and logins need to have a login policy.

name.description: Name of the OIDC client. Names need to be unique for a given customer ID.

redirectURIs.description: URLs you can redirect users to after they log in. When requesting authorization, your request needs to include one of these URLs. If it doesn’t, the request fails. A redirect URL can be either an `HTTPS` link or a mobile deep link. The only valid `HTTP` link is `localhost`.

tokenPolicy.description: Unique identifier of the token policy for the client. All OIDC clients need to have a token policy.

type.description: OIDC client type. Possible values are `confidential` and `public`. With a confidential client you need to pass the client secret in the authorization request. Public clients don’t have a client secret, meaning there's no secret to pass in the authorization request. You should use public clients for registering and logging in users.

schema.description: Creates an OpenID Connect (OIDC) client.

_links.description: Navigable hypermedia links for an OIDC client.

application_client.description: Configuration URL for the OIDC client's Identity Cloud application client. Application clients serve as a bridge between the Identity Cloud infrastructure and the OAuth and OIDC protocols. When you create an OIDC client, Identity Cloud automatically creates and assigns an application client.

href.description: Navigable hypermedia link to the application client.

self.description: Navigable hypermedia link for an OIDC client.

href.description: Configuration URL for the OIDC client.

id.description: Unique identifier of an OIDC client.

loginPolicy.description: Unique identifier of the OIDC client's login policy. OpenID Connect clients that handle user registrations and logins need to have a login policy.

name.description: Name of the OIDC client. Names need to be unique for a given customer ID.

redirectURIs.description: URLs you can redirect users to after they log in. When requesting authorization, your request needs to include one of these URLs. If it doesn’t, the request fails. A redirect URL can be either an `HTTPS` link or a mobile deep link. The only valid `HTTP` link is `localhost`.

tokenPolicy.description: Unique identifier of the token policy for the client. All OIDC clients need to have a token policy.

type.description: OIDC client type. Possible values are `confidential` and `public`. With a confidential client you need to pass the client secret in the authorization request. Public clients don’t have a client secret, meaning there's no secret to pass in the authorization request. Akamai recommends public clients for registering and logging in users.

schema.description: Typically occurs when you leave off a required member or when you misspell a member name.
Typically occurs because your administrative access token is invalid. Administrative access tokens expire after one hour.
You don't have permission to access the resource. Verify that your access token has the necessary permissions and then try again.
One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

Typically occurs when you try to delete a resource that another resource is using. For example, if you assign a token policy to an OpenID Connect client you can't delete that policy can't be without first unassigning it.

schema.description: Creates a login policy. Login policies help manage the user login and registration experience.

customClaims.description: User profile attributes that the standard scopes and claims don't return. See [Custom claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims#create-custom-claims) for more information. This documentation shows only two sample claims. However, you can configure most of the attributes in a user profile as custom claims.

id_token.description: Custom claims in the user's identity token.

userinfo.description: Custom claims available from the userinfo endpoint.

identityStoreDetails.description: Links the login policy to the Identity Cloud infrastructure. You need these values when you create a login policy. After that, these values are read-only.

connectionDetails.description: Configures connections to the Identity Cloud backend infrastructure.

applicationId.description: __Read-only__ Unique identifier of your Identity Cloud application. You can find your application ID on the Console's **Manage Application** page.

clientId.description: __Read-only__ Unique identifier of the login policy's `owner` client.

clientSecret.description: Client secret of the login policy's `owner` client.

domain.description: URL of your Identity Cloud Capture domain. Akamai provides you with this URL when you subscribe to Identity Cloud.

entityType.description: Name of the entity type that stores user profiles. The entity type of the login policy needs to match the entity type in your application client. See [Configure application client settings](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/configure-the-required-application-client-settings) for more information.

type.description: Login policy type. This value needs to be set to `janrainCapture`.

loginURL.description: URL of your Hosted Login sign-in page.

schema.description: Unique identifier of the new login policy.

201.description: Unique identifier of the new login policy.

schema.description: Typically occurs when you leave off a required member or when you misspell a member name.
You don't have permission to access the resource. Verify that your access token has the necessary permissions and then try again.
One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

In an authorization request, the `response_type` parameter specifies the items clients expect to get back from the authorization server following authentication. See [Supported response types](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/supported-response-types) for more information.

See [Supported response types](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/supported-response-types) for more information.

Push claims centralize and standardize the user profile information in an identity token or made available from the userinfo endpoint following authentication. See [Push claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/push-claims) for more information.

schema.description: Creates a token policy. Token policies specify token lifetimes and define the scopes for OpenID Connect clients.

accessTokenLifetime.description: Number of seconds that access tokens remain valid.

allowedScopes.description: Scopes you can access when using this token policy. A token policy can return fewer scopes than the ones in the discovery document, but can't return any scopes not in that document. If you leave this out, the token policy uses the scopes specified in the discovery document. See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.

refreshTokenLifetime.description: Number of seconds that refresh tokens remain valid.

useAccessJWT.description: If `true`, Hosted Login issues identity tokens as JSON Web Tokens (JWTs). Otherwise Hosted Login issues access tokens as standard (opaque) tokens. Unlike JWTs, only the introspection endpoint can decode standard tokens. See [Token reference](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/token-reference) for more information.

schema.description: Unique identifier for the new token policy.

201.description: Unique identifier of the new token policy.

schema.description: Typically occurs when you leave off a required member or when you misspell a member name.
You don't have permission to access the resource. Verify that your access token has the necessary permissions and then try again.
One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

schema.description: Returns a token policy. Token policies specify token lifetimes and define the scopes for OpenID Connect clients.

_links.description: Navigable hypermedia links for a token policy.

self.description: Navigable hypermedia links for a token policy.

href.description: Navigable hypermedia link to the token policy.

accessTokenLifetime.description: Number of seconds that access tokens remain valid.

allowedScopes.description: Scopes you can access when using this token policy. A token policy can return fewer scopes than the ones in the discovery document, but can't return any scopes not in that document. If you leave this out, the token policy uses the scopes specified in the discovery document. See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.

id.description: Unique identifier of a token policy.

refreshTokenLifetime.description: Number of seconds that refresh tokens remain valid.

useAccessJWT.description: If `true`, Hosted Login issues identity tokens as JSON Web Tokens (JWTs). If `false` or if left out, Hosted Login issues access tokens as standard opaque tokens. Unlike JWTs, only the introspection endpoint can decode standard tokens. See [Token reference](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/token-reference) for more information.

schema.description: You don't have permission to access the resource. Verify that your access token has the necessary permissions and then try again.
One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

schema.description: Modifies a token policy. Token policies specify token lifetimes and define the scopes for OpenID Connect clients.

accessTokenLifetime.description: Number of seconds that access tokens remain valid.

allowedScopes.description: Scopes you can access when using this token policy. A token policy can return fewer scopes than the ones in the discovery document, but can't return any scopes not in that document. If you leave this parameter out, the token policy uses the scopes specified in the discovery document. See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.

id.description: __Read-only__ Unique identifier of a token policy.

refreshTokenLifetime.description: Number of seconds that refresh tokens remain valid.

useAccessJWT.description: If `true`, Hosted Login issues identity tokens as JSON Web Tokens (JWTs). If `false` or if left out, Hosted Login issues access tokens as standard (opaque) tokens. Unlike JWTs, only the introspection endpoint can decode standard tokens. See [Token reference](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/token-reference) for more information.

See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.

delete.description: Deletes a token policy. Note that you can't delete a token policy currently in use by an OIDC client. That’s because OIDC clients always need to have a token policy. If you want to remove that token policy, start by modifying the OIDC client and assigning it a different token policy. After that you can delete the token policy.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

schema.description: You don't have permission to access the resource. Verify that your access token has the necessary permissions and then try again.
One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

Typically occurs when you try to delete a resource that another resource is using. For example, if you assign a token policy to an OpenID Connect client you can't delete that policy can't be without first unassigning it.

parameters.description: Unique identifier of a Hosted Login token policy. Use the [Get token policies](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-hosted-login/reference/get-token-policies) operation to return the IDs of your token policies.
parameters.name: tokenPolicyId

get.description: Returns the grant types available to a token policy. A grant is a standard methodology for obtaining tokens and, in turn, obtaining access to protected resources. See [Supported authorization grant types](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/supported-authorization-grant-types-1#manage-allowed-grant-types) for more information.

See [Supported authorization grant types](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/supported-authorization-grant-types-1#manage-allowed-grant-types) for more information.

200.description: Grant types available to the token policy.

schema.description: You don't have permission to access the resource. Verify that your access token has the necessary permissions and then try again.
One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.
This typically means that the JSON in your request didn't pass validation. Verify your JSON syntax and then try again.

parameters.description: Unique identifier of a Hosted Login token policy. Use the [Get token policies](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-hosted-login/reference/get-token-policies) operation to return the IDs of your token policies.
parameters.name: tokenPolicyId

get.description: Returns the discovery document. This document a set of OpenID Connect (OIDC) values accessible to OpenID Connect clients. These values enable clients to self-configure. You don't need authorization to call this operation.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

schema.description: OpenID Connect (OIDC) values available to OIDC clients. The discovery document, also known as the _well-known endpoint_, provides a way for OIDC clients to self-configure.

acr_values_supported.description: Authentication Context Class References (ACR). These references, which represent different methods of authentication, come from the National Institute of Standards and Technology’s Authenticator Assurance Levels. See [Risk-based authentication](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/risk-based-authentication-and-client-reputation#the-acr_values-parameter) for more information.

claims_parameter_supported.description: Indicates whether you can use the `claims` parameter in authorization requests.

claims_supported.description: OpenID Connect claims. Each claim represents a single piece of user information, such as the user’s first name or cell phone number. See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.

code_challenge_methods_supported.description: Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE) code challenge methods. Hosted Login only supports the `S256` code challenge method. This method is also known as `SHA-256` or `Secure Hash Algorithm`. See [Authorization code + PKCE grant type](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/the-authorization-code-pkce-grant-type) for more information.

grant_types_supported.description: Methods for obtaining an access token. See [Supported authorization grant types](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/supported-authorization-grant-types) for more information.

id_token_signing_alg_values_supported.description: Algorithms for signing JSON web tokens. Hosted Login only supports the `RS256` signing algorithm.

introspection_endpoint.description: URL of the introspection endpoint. This endpoint validates access and refresh tokens.

issuer.description: Base URL for your implementation of Hosted Login.

jwks_uri.description: URL of your JSON Web Key Set (JWKS). JSON web keys are public cryptographic keys for verifying the signatures of identity tokens.

request_parameter_supported.description: If `true`, you can use the `request` parameter in authorization requests. The `request` parameter combines all your query parameters into a single JSON web token.

response_modes_supported.description: Specifies the different ways an authorization server can respond after a user logs in. See [Supported response modes](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/supported-response-modes) for more information.

response_types_supported.description: Specifies the items you receive following a successful authentication. See [Supported response types](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/supported-response-types) for more information.

revocation_endpoint.description: URL of the revocation endpoint. This endpoint revokes access and refresh tokens.

scopes_supported.description: OpenID Connect scopes. Scopes are a collection of claims, with each claim typically representing a single piece of user information, such as a user’s first name or cell phone number. See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.

subject_types_supported.description: Subject Identifier types. Currently Hosted Login only supports the `public` type, in which the server issues a user a single unique identifier. The user then employs this identity on all of their clients.

token_endpoint_auth_methods_supported.description: Client authentication methods for the token endpoint. Hosted Login currently supports the `client_secret_post` method, in which the client sends authentication information as part of the request body in an HTTP POST, and the `client_secret_basic` method. In the latter method, the client passes a user ID and password to the server as part of the `Authorization` header. Akamai recommends using `client_secret_basic` only on a secure connection.

userinfo_endpoint.description: URL of the userinfo endpoint. This endpoint makes user profile information available to OpenID Connect clients.

schema.description: One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

post.description: Requests Hosted Login authorization for an end user. You don't need authorization to call this endpoint.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

parameters.description: Unique identifier of the OpenID Connect login client making the authorization request. Use the [Get OpenID Connect clients](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-hosted-login/reference/get-oidc-clients) operation to return the IDs of your OpenID Connect clients.
parameters.name: clientId

parameters.description: __Enum__ Type of response you're requesting from the authorization server. Responses consist of various combinations of `code`, `token`, and `identity token`. See [Supported response types](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/supported-response-types) for more information.
parameters.name: response_type

parameters.description: __Enum__ OpenID Connect (OIDC) scopes accessible from the userinfo endpoint after a user logs in. All Hosted Login authorization requests need to include this parameter and, at a minimum, specify the `openid` scope. This tells the authorization server that you want to authenticate by using OpenID Connect. Your token policy determines the other scopes available to you. If you request a scope the token policy doesn't support, Hosted Login ignores that request. See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.
parameters.name: scope

parameters.description: URL that Hosted Login redirects a user to after the user logs in. The redirect URL needs to match one of the URLs in the login client’s `redirectURIs` property.
parameters.name: redirect_uri

parameters.description: Authentication value that the user's OpenID Connect client generates. The server verifies this value before the client exchanges an authorization code for a set of tokens. If verification fails, the exchange doesn't take place. Use this parameter only with Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE) authorizations. See [Authorization code + PKCE grant type](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/the-authorization-code-pkce-grant-type) for more information.
parameters.name: code_challenge

parameters.description: __Enum__ Hashing algorithm for generating the value of the `code_challenge` parameter. For Hosted Login, this is always `S256`.
parameters.name: code_challenge_method

parameters.description: Random string value in an authorization request. This value helps protect against cross-site request forgeries (CSRF). After they log in, Hosted Login redirects users to the URL in the `redirect_uri` parameter. At the same time, Hosted Login adds this value to the redirect URL. That value needs to match the value of the `state` parameter from the original authentication request. If the values don't match that could indicate a cross-site request forgery attack.
parameters.name: state

parameters.description:
__Enum__ Specifies which screen, if any, displays when a user makes an authorization request. Valid options are:

- `none`. Hosted Login checks to see if the client has a valid session. If a valid session is found, the user skips authentication and goes directly the redirect URL. If a valid session isn't found, a `No authenticated session found` error displays and the user needs to reauthenticate.
- `login`. The sign-in screen displays.
- `create`. The registration screen displays.
parameters.name: prompt

parameters.description: Number of seconds before a session automatically expires. After the session expires, users need to reauthenticate if they want to access a protected resource.
parameters.name: max_age

parameters.description: Language or locale for displaying Hosted Login screens. Configure your language preferences as a space-delimited set of RFC 5646 language codes. The default value is `en-US`, the code for US English. See [Supported languages and locales](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/hosted-login-supported-languages-and-locales) for more information.
parameters.name: ui_locales

parameters.description: Email address of the user requesting authorization. This parameter makes the email address automatically appear in the sign-in screen’s **Email Address** field. That means users only have to enter their password to log in. Keep in mind that Hosted Login can't determine the user's email address. Instead, you'll need to use an alternate approach to identify, and to store, that email address.
parameters.name: login_hint

parameters.description: Specifies the user profile claims available after a user logs in. These claims can be either standard OpenID Connect claims or custom claims your organization creates and then defines in your login policies. See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.
parameters.name: claims

schema.description: OpenID Connect (OIDC) claims.

id_token.description: OIDC claims for the identity token. One sample claim is shown in this documentation. You can configure most of the attributes in a user profile as a claim.

userinfo.description: OIDC claims for the userinfo endpoint. One sample claim is shown in this documentation. You can configure most of the attributes in a user profile as a claim.

parameters.description: __Enum__ Specifies how the sign-in screen displays. Under the default `page` value, Hosted Login redirects the user to a standalone sign-in screen. If set to `popup`, the sign-in screen appears in a pop-up window, with no redirection needed.
parameters.name: display

parameters.description: Random string value in an authorization request. After users log in, their identity token includes the `nonce` claim. For the identity token to be valid, the value of the `nonce` claim in the token needs to match the value of this parameter.
parameters.name: nonce

parameters.description: Limits an access token to a specific set of protected resources. See [Secure audience injection and the resource parameter](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/secure-audience-injection-and-the-resource-parameter) for more information.
parameters.name: resource

schema.description: Comma-separated list of the protected resources accessible to the token.
Requests Hosted Login authorization for an end user.

access_token.description: Bearer token that defines Hosted Login permissions.

expires_in_token.description: Number of seconds before the access token expires.

identity_token.description: JSON Web Token (JWT) containing user information.

refresh_token.description: Token you can use to obtain a new access token after the current access token expires. By default, access tokens are valid for 60 minutes.

scope.description: Space-delimited set of OpenID Connect scopes the token can access. Scopes represent different sets of user profile attributes. For example, the `profile` scope returns data such as the user’s name, gender, and date of birth. See [Scopes and claims](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/scopes-and-claims) for more information.

token_type.description: Always set to `Bearer`. This means that the token permissions go to the user who possesses the token.

get.description: Returns your JSON web keys. JSON web keys are public cryptographic keys for verifying the signatures on Hosted Login identity tokens. You don't need authorization to call this operation.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

schema.description: Returns your JSON web keys. These are public cryptographic keys that verify the signatures on Hosted Login identity tokens.

keys.description: JSON web keys available to you.

alg.description: Cryptographic algorithm for signing identity tokens. Hosted Login only supports `RS256`, the RSA Digital Signature Algorithm with SHA-256 encryption algorithm.

e.description: Along with the modulus (`m`), generates public key values. The exponent is typically set to `65537` or `AQAB` when Base64urlUInt-encoded.

kid.description: Identifier for a JSON web key. Note that these values don’t need to be unique. Instead, two keys can have the same ID as long as they differ in other ways, such as key use or key type.

kty.description: Cryptographic algorithm family for the key. Hosted Login only supports the `RSA` (Rivest–Shamir–Adleman) algorithm.

n.description: Along with the exponent (`e`), generates public key values.

use.description: Indicates whether a public key encrypts data or verifies the signature on data. For Hosted Login, this value is always `sig`. Hosted Login only uses JSON web keys to verify identity token signatures.

200.description: Information about your JSON web keys.

schema.description: One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

post.description: Requests an administrative access token. Use token to call the other Hosted Login configuration operations.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

application/x-www-form-urlencoded.example:
--boundary
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="grant_type",

client_credentials

--boundary
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="scope",

*.**

schema.description: Requests an administrative access token.

grant_type.description: Type of grant. This needs to be set to `client_credentials`.

scope.description: Permissions for the administrative access token. The scope `*:**` gives the bearer of the token full access to Hosted Login. See [Use different scopes in your administrative access tokens](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/how-to-use-different-scopes-in-your-configuration-access-tokens-1) for information on other available scopes.

schema.description: Returns an administrative access token. You use an administrative access token to call the other Hosted Login operations.

access_token.description: Access token for calling the other Hosted Login API operations.

expires_in.description: Number of seconds the access token remains valid. Note that there's no administrative access refresh token. Instead, when an access token expires, you need to retrieve a new token. By default access tokens expire after one hour.

scope.description: Space-delimited set of permissions for the user in possession of the token. For example, the scope `*:**` provides full permissions to Hosted Login. See [Get Started](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud-hosted-login/reference/get-started) for information on setting different administrative access scopes.

token_type.description: Always set to `Bearer`. This means that the token permissions go to the user who possesses the token.

schema.description: One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

post.description: Returns the current state of a Hosted Login access or refresh token. If the token is active the operation returns additional claims belonging to the token.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

schema.description: Validates a token.
Returns the current status of a Hosted Login access token or refresh token. If the token is active the operation returns additional claims belonging to the token.

acr.description: Level of authentication the user underwent during login. The acronym is short for Authentication Context Class Reference. See [Risk-based authentication](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/risk-based-authentication-and-client-reputation) for more information.

active.description: If `true`, the token is valid. If `false` this is the only value the operation returns. For security reasons, Hosted Login provides no information explaining why a token is invalid.

amr.description: Specifies the authentication methods responsible for the `acr` authentication level. See [The amr claim](https://techdocs.akamai.com/identity-cloud/docs/risk-based-authentication-and-client-reputation#the-amr-claim) for more information.

aud.description: Audiences for the token. These are typically OpenID Connect clients.

auth_time.description: Epoch timestamp indicating the user's last authentication.

client_id.description: Unique identifier of the OIDC client from the original authorization request.

exp.description: Epoch timestamp indicating when the token expires.

iat.description: Epoch timestamp indicating the issue date for the token.

scope.description: OpenID Connect scopes the token can access.

sub.description: Unique identifier of the end user. This is typically the user’s Identity Cloud UUID.

token_type.description: Always set to `Bearer`. This means that the token permissions go to the user who possesses the token.

schema.description: One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

post.summary: Introspect an access or refresh token

post.description: Revokes an access token or refresh token. After you revoke an access token that token no longer provides access to protected resources. To restore access the user needs to reauthenticate. After you revoke a refresh token, you can no longer use that token to request a new access token. The only way to get a new refresh token is to reauthenticate. You don't need authorization to call this endpoint.

externalDocs.description: See documentation for this operation in Akamai's Identity Cloud Hosted Login API

application/x-www-form-urlencoded.example:
--boundary
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="token",

CKTYZfelql9QKStDfx70Leb7BfLZAXNC25WJOPlX8FrUEqUxeAHpKudUkKhBloq6

--boundary
Content-Disposition: form-data; name="client_id",

d0b077ce-c01e-4150-99d7-f0eae7f00f78

schema.description: Revokes an access token.

client_id.description: Unique identifier of the OIDC client from the original authorization request.

token.description: Access token or refresh token you're revoking.

text/plain.example: The token was revoked successfully or the token was invalid.

schema.description: Indicates that the token is no longer valid. To improve security, Hosted Login tells you if it had to revoke the token, or if the token wasn't valid in the first place. You only know that the token isn't valid now.
One or more items in your path is invalid. Verify each path component and then try again.

post.summary: Revoke an access or refresh token
